Title: Posterior parietal cortex in Rhesus monkey: II. Evidence for segregated corticocortical networks linking sensory and limbic areas with the frontal lobe.
Comments: This article reports frontal label from the same experiments as in the companion paper CG89a.

@BrainMaps.Comments: Parietal areas are defined according to the delineation of the companion paper (CG89a).

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "We shall use the term FEF here to refer to the cortex bounded by the superior and inferior limbs of the arcuate sulcus, which includes its anterior bank, as well as the caudal end of the principal sulcus, and the dorsal convexity cortex between these sulci ... Cytoarchiteconically, it is approximately coextensive with Walker's area 8A, and possibly with the dorsal part of Walker's area 45 (see Bruce et al., 1985)."

"We shall use the term FEF here to refer to the cortex bounded by the superior and inferior limbs of the arcuate sulcus, which includes its anterior bank, as well as the caudal end of the principal sulcus, and the dorsal convexity cortex between these sulci ... Cytoarchiteconically, it is approximately coextensive with Walker's area 8A, and possibly with the dorsal part of Walker's area 45 (see Bruce et al., 1985)."

"We shall use the term FEF here to refer to the cortex bounded by the superior and inferior limbs of the arcuate sulcus, which includes its anterior bank, as well as the caudal end of the principal sulcus, and the dorsal convexity cortex between these sulci ... Cytoarchiteconically, it is approximately coextensive with Walker's area 8A, and possibly with the dorsal part of Walker's area 45 (see Bruce et al., 1985)."

"Given the discrepancies about cytoarchitectonic boundaries between the frontal motor areas of macaques ... the terms motor cortex (equivalent to primary motor cortex, MI, and roughly to area 4 in Brodmann, 1909) , premotor cortex ... and supplementary motor cortex ... are used here." (p. 425)

"Given the discrepancies about cytoarchitectonic boundaries between the frontal motor areas of macaques ... the terms motor cortex ..., premotor cortex (roughly equivalent to Brodmann's lateral area 6), and supplementary motor cortex (supplementary motor area (SMA, also known as MII, and corresponding approximately to Brodmann's dorsomedial area 6) are used here. For details about the location and extension of these areas see Wise (1985), Wiesendanger (1986), and Mitz and Wise (1987). Electrical stimulation of the rostrodorsal part of SMA elicits orofacial and eye movements (Mitz and Wise, 1987)." (p. 425)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Mitz and Wise defined the supplementary motor area (which they call area 6m) electrophysiologically. Their work is often cited as a "standard reference" for the definition of SMA.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Given the discrepancies about cytoarchitectonic boundaries between the frontal motor areas of macaques ... the terms motor cortex ..., premotor cortex (roughly equivalent to Brodmann's lateral area 6), and supplementary motor cortex ... are used here ... The premotor cortex is subdivided into a dorsal and a ventral sector, the boundary between them lying at the level of the genu of the arcuate sulcus (Matelli et al., 1985; Barbas and Pandya, 1987)." (p. 425)

"Given the discrepancies about cytoarchitectonic boundaries between the frontal motor areas of macaques ... the terms motor cortex ..., premotor cortex (roughly equivalent to Brodmann's lateral area 6), and supplementary motor cortex ... are used here ... The premotor cortex is subdivided into a dorsal and a ventral sector, the boundary between them lying at the level of the genu of the arcuate sulcus (Matelli et al., 1985; Barbas and Pandya, 1987)." (p. 425)

"Given the discrepancies about cytoarchitectonic boundaries between the frontal motor areas of macaques ... the terms motor cortex ..., premotor cortex (roughly equivalent to Brodmann's lateral area 6), and supplementary motor cortex ... are used here ... The premotor cortex is subdivided into a dorsal and a ventral sector, the boundary between them lying at the level of the genu of the arcuate sulcus (Matelli et al., 1985; Barbas and Pandya, 1987)." (p. 425)

"Given the discrepancies about cytoarchitectonic boundaries between the frontal motor areas of macaques ... the terms motor cortex ..., premotor cortex (roughly equivalent to Brodmann's lateral area 6), and supplementary motor cortex ... are used here ... The premotor cortex is subdivided into a dorsal and a ventral sector, the boundary between them lying at the level of the genu of the arcuate sulcus (Matelli et al., 1985; Barbas and Pandya, 1987)." (p. 425)

"Given the discrepancies about cytoarchitectonic boundaries between the frontal motor areas of macaques ... the terms motor cortex ..., premotor cortex (roughly equivalent to Brodmann's lateral area 6), and supplementary motor cortex ... are used here ... The premotor cortex is subdivided into a dorsal and a ventral sector, the boundary between them lying at the level of the genu of the arcuate sulcus (Matelli et al., 1985; Barbas and Pandya, 1987)." (p. 425)

"Given the discrepancies about cytoarchitectonic boundaries between the frontal motor areas of macaques ... the terms motor cortex ..., premotor cortex (roughly equivalent to Brodmann's lateral area 6), and supplementary motor cortex ... are used here ... The premotor cortex is subdivided into a dorsal and a ventral sector, the boundary between them lying at the level of the genu of the arcuate sulcus (Matelli et al., 1985; Barbas and Pandya, 1987)." (p. 425)
"... supplementary motor area (SMA, also known as MII, and corresponding approximately to Brodmann's dorsomedial area 6) ..."

"Given the discrepancies about cytoarchitectonic boundaries between the frontal motor areas of macaques ... the terms motor cortex ..., premotor cortex (roughly equivalent to Brodmann's lateral area 6), and supplementary motor cortex (supplementary motor area (SMA, also known as MII, and corresponding approximately to Brodmann's dorsomedial area 6) are used here ... Electrical stimulation of the rostrodorsal part of SMA elicits orofacial and eye movements (Mitz and Wise, 1987). On the basis of its oculomotor properties, Schlag and Schlag-Rey (1987) have defined this cortex as the supplementary eye field." (p. 425)

@Injections.Citation: "The HRP-WGA was injected on the medial parietal cortex ventral and posterior to the posterior end of the cingulate sulcus (Fig. 2). The injection fell well within the boundaries of area 7m, without any appreciable involvement of neighboring areas or the underlying white matter." (p. 425)
@Injections.Comments: Resulting label from this injection are described in two companion papers: CG89a describes label in parietal, temporal, cingulate, and occipital cortex, whereas CG89b describes label in frontal cortices.

@Injections.Citation: "In case 2, the HRP-WGA injection was placed in the caudal one-third of the posterior parietal lobe and included the posterior part of area 7a (Fig. 4). It extended slightly onto the medial bank of the posterior superior temporal sulcus and onto the lip of the posterior bank of the intraparietal sulcus. While the most medial needle track was entirely confined within the cortex, the lateral track reached the boundary between the cortex and the white matter. However, there was no evidence of spurious uptake of the tracer by fibers of regions other than 7a (Cavada and Goldman-Rakic, 1989)." (pp. 425-428)
@Injections.Comments: Resulting label from this injection are described in two companion papers: CG89a describes label in parietal, temporal, cingulate, and occipital cortex, whereas CG89b describes label in frontal cortices.

@Injections.Citation: "The HRP-WGA injection was placed in the anterior half of the posterior parietal lobe, within area 7b, with no involvement of the underlying white matter or of neighboring areas." (p. 435)
@Injections.Comments: Resulting label from this injection are described in two companion papers: CG89a describes label in parietal, temporal, cingulate, and occipital cortex, whereas CG89b describes label in frontal cortices.

@Injections.Citation: "The injection in case 4 was the largest in the series and spanned areas 7a and 7b (Fig. 8). However, the most anterior, most posterior, and most lateral parts of the posterior parietal lobe were not included within the injection area. Two of the needle tracks, in the most medial part of the posterior parietal convexity, traversed the border between the cortex and the white matter but were less than 1 mm deep from this border. Sections through the central sulcus were not processed." (pp. 435-436)
@Injections.Comments: Resulting label from this injection are described in two companion papers: CG89a describes label in parietal, temporal, cingulate, and occipital cortex, whereas CG89b describes label in frontal cortices.

@Injections.Citation: "Connections of area 7ip (cases 5 and 6) ... In cases 5 and 6, the HRP-WGA injections were situated in approximately the middle of the posterior bank of the intraparietal sulcus, involving the superficial three-fourths of the bank and sparing the deeper one-fourth.The findings in both cases were essentially similar, and therefore we describe and illustrate here those of case 5, in which the needle tracks were well confined within the thickness of the cortex." (p. 437)
@Injections.Comments: Resulting label from this injection are described in two companion papers: CG89a describes label in parietal, temporal, cingulate, and occipital cortex, whereas CG89b describes label in frontal cortices.

publication.title: Posterior parietal cortex in Rhesus monkey: II. Evidence for segregated corticocortical networks linking sensory and limbic areas with the frontal lobe.
